segments.text: Yeah, we'll talk a little bit, and then I'll go back and test it, and then we'll start over again.
And this is how I'm going to start out.
This is an interview with Mr. Kerry Colley by Danny West on April 29, 1991, at his place of business in Bryan, Texas, concerning the civil rights movement.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge, I am asking you to donate these tapes to me or to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
That's fine.
Okay.
First, I'm going to just ask a couple of background questions.
First of all, where and when were you born?
On November 4, 1941, in Brunner, Alabama.
Okay.
And where were you raised?
Were you raised in Alabama?
Alabama.
Until when did you move to Texas?
I came to Texas in 62.
Oh, okay, good.
I have a question to ask you later on that maybe you'll be able to answer that one, too.
And since you were raised in the South, I assume that whites and blacks attended both segregated schools.
Correct.
How did the white schools compare with the black schools?
There was no comparison.
There was no comparison.
Our school had a potbellied stove with coal, and it was wooden structure that was...
appeared to be hundreds of years old.
And the white school was a nice brick structure with central heating and what have you.
The books that we received were like hand-me-down books.
They were books that were out of date, books that had adopted a new set.
And we got the older books.
Even basketball was played outdoors at our school on the ground.
We didn't have a gym.
There were gyms and things like this at the white school.
So that was a marked difference between the schools.
Were those schools ever integrated before you left?
No.
Were they long after?
Long, long after.
They were some of the last to be integrated.
And today there, what they've done to get around integration, only the poor whites go to the county and the city schools.
The middle and upper class whites go to an academy, a private academy that has been established.
Let's see.
Okay, this is the one I was going to ask you about, maybe you knew about locally.
Locally, I was talking with my teacher, and he said that he heard that the Bryan High School was burned down, or that it burned down, and that's how they ended up integrating the school system.
I was not in 62.
I was teaching school at the time.
I was in 70.
Here in... 69, yes.
It didn't burn.
The Bryan High School didn't burn down.
That was the...
Old Bryant, the original Old Bryant colored high, which was at that time was an elementary school, Washington Elementary, which is right across the street here, where this park is now.
It burned.
And I taught at Neal Junior High, which was the old Kemp High school.
It burned.
It was all within the same year.
Oh, really?
Yeah.
Within the same year.
Less than six months apart.
And did they have to, what did they do after, did they?
Well, at first, we were crowded into the black schools.
And as a result of these schools burning, though, it speeded up the process of integration.
At the time, Bryan was in a grade-a-year plan to integrate the schools.
There was an old system devised by the South to delay
integration as much as possible.
So if you went to court, you could get, say, well, we'll integrate one grade a year.

Right, OK. And also at that time, a lawsuit had been filed by the NAACP, a gentleman that lives right up here on the corner, Jaylev Thomas, because of his son, Clarence Thomas, who wanted to go to the schools here.
And as a result of that, the court suit and the fires and all the things that were happening at the time, the schools weren't integrated.
How did blacks feel, for the most part, about integration at the time?
I mean, did they want to do that?
To answer you honestly, not really.
But the only way that they felt that they could get an equal school with a quality education, same facility, was to go to the same school.
You can't have, no two things are exactly alike.
You can't have separate and equal.
Separate is, as the Supreme Court has said, the end of itself is unequal.
There were some blacks who wanted to go to the white schools.
There were some that didn't.
There were a lot of fears and pressures on the blacks at the time.
But in spite of those fears and pressures, they felt that for their children, and the children felt for themselves, that it was the best thing that could have happened.
How did you perceive whites to feel about it?
Were they just as scared about it?
They had anxieties, too.
And there were some who looked down on blacks.
And this is my personal feeling from what I saw and observed.
You had the elite group.
And most of the towns in the south, they leave whites.
We kind of ran the town.
And the poor whites were just as bad off as the blacks.
They just didn't realize it.
But the only thing that they had that was better than the blacks was that they were white.
And they felt like, you know, I'm
speculating on this, that if my child goes to school with this black child, then somehow it brings us down a lot too.
So that was a tremendous resistance to it.
One of the books that we talked about, I don't know if you've heard of it before, it's called Black Like Me.
Yeah, Ralph Ellison.
Yeah.

And we read that, and one of the quotes in there is he was just talking about how just after a few days, how he'd been in the South, he said that it just became very obvious to him that the black man knew nothing about the white man, and the white man was totally ignorant of the black man, also that they were ignorant of each other.
Two separate societies.
How do you feel about that?
Well, he's correct.
There did exist two separate societies.
I may be a little bit, in one sense, a little bit more fortunate than some other blacks.
My granddad and my great granddad were both land owners.
And my dad was in business.
And as a result of the respect that my granddad had
and my dad had acquired in their separate communities, there was some interaction.
Also, my great-grandmother.
Between the white?
Between my family, and so I knew some of the white man's ways.
My great-grandmother and my grandmother's dads were white.
And there were some whites who did look out for their offspring.
But my granddad was black, Jamaican, and there were the two separate societies.
In spite of, in one sense of the word, not being as economically or educationally
deprived as a lot of blacks were.
I still knew there were two separate worlds.
I only, and I still was looked at, or we were still appeared at in that subservient role.
But because of the strength of those things and the callers tended to know a little bit more about the black man.
I mean the white man than the average black man.
Because my parents, my grandparents both had college degrees.
Oh, they did?
Yeah, Tuskegee Institute.
So, consequently, my grandmother was a teacher.
My grandfather on my father's side had little or no education.
But on my mother's side, both my mother's parents were.
I graduated from the College of Tuskegee Institute.
So that put you in just a different perspective than a lot of others.
Yeah, somewhat different perspective, even though there were things that happened to my family that equalized the situation.
Like my father's business was burned, which equalizes the banks.
wouldn't loan him money, he had to leave and go to another state to make some money to come back and reestablish himself.
So, you know, I was in one sense, and I wasn't in the other sense.
So.
Now, I just wanted to ask you a little bit about voting.
And were you registered to vote when you when you became of legal age or?
Yes, I was registered.
My dad registered the vote.
He did?
One of the few blacks in Pike County.
At one time, I was probably the only black in Pike County, Alabama, that was registered.
Did he have to take one of the understanding tests?
I went with him.
Really?
And they asked him a bunch of crazy questions.
Specific little Article 2 section, that kind of thing?
Well, this is kind of to show you the kind of thing that they're asking.
I never will forget the answer my dad gave.
What you had were people who themselves were uneducated, given these tests, and they asked my dad one question I remember just distinctly.
How many bubbles were there in a bar, a four ounce bar of ivory soap?
Really?
What did he say?
Well, my dad told him that he would have to measure the precise size of it and everything, but if you use the formula E equals MC squared, you can find it.
And I asked him later on, what was that?
E equals MC squared.
He said, oh, they're dumb.
They don't know the answers to their own questions.
So they thought he knew what he was talking about.
Yeah, they thought he knew what he was talking about.
By God, he's a smart nigga.
I wanted to ask you a little bit more about, now I wanted to ask you a little bit more about when you actually became involved in the Civil Rights Movement.
When did you start becoming involved?
My family became involved with the original Bush boycott.
My dad in 1955.
I was doing pretty well in business at the time.
In Birmingham?
No, in Brundage.
I was not in Birmingham.
Did they have Best Boy Cuts like that?
No, it was in Montgomery only, where it originally began.
My hometown is only about 52 miles from Montgomery.
My mom and dad, I knew a lot about Montgomery because my little hometown only had about
Well, they had less than 2,000 people.
And we went to Montgomery to shop.
Oh, I see.
It was one of the few times that you went to, they had a Woolworth's there.
And I could go in and eat hot dogs.
Right.
But there were two sections, black section and white section.
So when this, and my parents were always involved with the NAACP.
And the NAACP was the group that really was behind the boycott.
Dr. King was just chosen.
And Dr. King was chosen because he had not been tainted by the white power structure.
What they did with most of the ministers, they like bought them off.
And Dr. King was the new kid on the block.
And the NAACP felt that he hadn't been there long enough.
to be tainted.
Ms. Rosa Parks herself was the secretary of the Montgomery Chapel of the NAACP.
Oh, really?
So the lady who refused to give up a seat.
And this thing had been tried back in 54.
I'm going to run the phone.
OK. Rodney, take this with you up there.
OK.
In 54, I knew this because
I remember my parents discussing and talking about it.
You had no TV or radio at the time.
And on top of that, I was a paper boy for my little hometown.
For both sections, you had two papers.
The white paper had one star.
The black paper had two stars on it.
But because my dad was an efficient person, he was allowed to deliver both.
Oh.
The white paper and the black paper.
They trusted him with that?
Yeah, well, but consequently, you got the opportunity to read what was in both papers.
Uh-huh.
And, uh, black paper had a slant to the knee for blacks.
Really?
And, you know, it had a different slant for whites.
To keep him uninformed about...
Right.
Hold on a second.
People want to hear?
Oh, you just...
They had kind of a slant.
Yeah.
Well, you know, to be a bit more specific, so my dad helped, you know, he sent money and a car to Montgomery, so they had transport.
My first real, I never, my parents, even though they themselves were, you know, active in what they could do at the time,
Most of the whites felt my dad was crazy, you know.
But they tried to protect the children like any parent would do.
And my dad, he told me when I left home going to Tuskegee, you know, not to get involved with anything.
But then Dr. King came to a church off campus one night.
We were just talking about, I wanted to ask you also about, you had said that your father sent some cars to Montgomery.
You had read a little bit about that, about trying to get some alternative things for the buses.
Yeah, well, my dad sent cars and money to the movement up there.
Uh, what happened, they asked people all over Alabama, blacks all over Alabama, to help support these people.
And, you know, naturally, economically, blacks, you know, were still relatively poor.
Uh, were relatively, you know, poor.
But they, those, you know, they spent what they could, a dollar.
Right.
You know, a quarter, fifty cents, you know, just a little bit.
Sure.
For every little bit of help.
Right.
And also they donated money for the court suits that followed.
And so that's about the time already, that's when you started getting exposed to the pistol?
Yeah, yeah, during that time.
There were a lot of racial incidents that happened to me as a kid.
There were things that happened to me as a kid.
There were things that happened and things that didn't happen, you know, as a kid.
You know, that let me know that I was different in some respects.
Some things, though, made me know that I was also equal.
I was even superior to some people.
But there were things that kind of let you know where you stood.
If you saw a white man coming down the street, a white woman, then you had to move off the side of the street and let them by.
Or if a white lady had on shorts, you better not look at them.
You might get put in jail.
When I was a kid, my dad came to that town and bought property on the north side.
And the town kind of grew around him.
And he sold his land to anybody.
So four houses down from us have a white family.
Oh, really?
And this kid, Winston, and I were like the same age.
And we went.
He was white.
He was a white kid.
And he went to a separate school.
The kid next door was black, and the next door, immediately.
But there was Winston, and then you had the Bars who lived a little bit further up north of us.
On the same Main Street.
My dad, which is unusual for a black to live on Main Street in a southern town, but it just happened that he
They come there early and they bought the property early.
And when nobody wanted it, when they built a highway through there and made the property, you know, badly.
Right.
Yeah.
But there were things that happened.
I saw kids.
I saw one girl get her teeth knocked down.
When we were little kids, I mean like 12 years old,
because we were in line.
What could provoke someone to do, I mean?
Because you were black.
The town is made like a Y.
And I guess, if I could say.
The town is made like a Y, like this is Main Street.
If you come up here in 231 or take you to Troy, Alabama, it winds around it.
You know, they had no rhyme or reason for the way they did.
But they also had a highway where we lived, which was also Main Street.
It came up this way.
And kids, you know, this girl and I met at the Y.
Not by chance.
The little girl?
The little girl.
Uh-huh.
My dad sent me to the post office, which is located up here, I guess about a half mile down.
And town had two sides to it.
And we went walking, looking in the windows on the various stores and everything down there.
And I was late.
We were late.
because your parents didn't want you to stay out too long because they would probably whip you or something like that.
We were standing in line at the post office to buy a stamp.
And we were next up to the counter.
And people kept coming around us, getting waiting on them.
And they were whites.
And this was like in the middle of the day.
And so the blacks and most of them were working.
And so, you know, the girl said, Mr., we're next, you know.
And, you know, told us to shut up.
And so three or four more people.
And we weren't saying anything out of disrespect to them.
We just didn't want to get a whipping when we got home.
Right.
And so she said, Mr., we're next, we're next.
And he just reached over the counter and hit her in the mouth.
Oh, to the post?
The postmaster.

And, you know, blood was everywhere, you know, and I said, well, you know, I told him, I said, well, sir, you didn't have to hit her, you know, and he reached over to hit me, but there was a white man there, and this white man called his hand and said, don't hit that boy.
Well, that's Kerry Colley's son.
Oh, man.
But as I said, they thought my dad was crazy, because he didn't take anything off anybody.
He was a crazy nigga.
And he didn't work for whites either.
So by virtue of that, he did do contract work, but he would not go and work an 8 to 5 job.
But anyway, that's it.
So he didn't really have anybody to answer to or that could harass him?
No.
We sold out goods.
We sold out goods to everybody.
in the community, black and white, because my dad was the only store that opened at 5 o'clock in the morning.
And it was the only store that was open at night after 5 o'clock in the afternoon.
So consequently, everybody bought from us.
So they had another little thing in my hometown on Thursday at noon, everything closed.
And his was the only store that was open.
on, you know, Saturday evenings, or after church on Sunday, he'd open.
I guess it's kind of the forerunner of the convenience store.
But, you know, they knew him, and so that happened, but I have had incidents that were, did happen to me.
So I knew in one sense where I stood, and I knew in another sense where I stood, too.
But getting back to this...
The first time I was involved, Dr. King came to the Tuskegee.
And they told us not to go over to the president and everything.
At your college?
Yeah, I said, don't go over there.
So we went anyway.
You know, a bunch of kids.
Right.
You know, somebody tell you don't do something when you're a kid.
You know, that's a thing that you really.
Were you about 20-ish or not?
No, I was only 17.
I was a freshman at the time.
Oh, okay.
First year.
And I went.
And he spoke.
And I feel like I had to march.
You know, he was just that eloquent.
A spokesman.
Yeah.
And, you know, he was saying what was happening in Tuskegee.
In that county there, you had a county where Tuskegee dominated that county.
like Texas A&M dominates, rather.
And even though it was a black institution, you had a learned black population there.
You had blacks with money and land.
And you had a majority of the population was black.
But the whites, through fear, kept the,
I would just say the so-called locals, a lot like it is here, at bay, you know, with stuff.
And it was the people, the average run-of-the-mill person that, you know, really the marchers benefited the most because you had, always had a black elite.
People don't realize it, but you've always had a black elite.
You even had blacks who owned slaves themselves.
I'm sure you've all heard about that.
But we went anyway, and Dr. King said something that night that stuck with me.
Even though he said that we might get killed, bad things could happen to us, he said that if a man wasn't willing to die for something, that his life wasn't worth living.

And, you know, you said, you know, you emphasized the point that if you didn't feel strong enough about a wrong or injustice or anything that you were fully committed to it, then you weren't much of a person.
And it went on and on.
You know, you heard speeches and you were ready to march.
Yeah.
Right.
And that's how, really, I got involved.
And you probably, did you ever hear of Congressman John Lewis?
I wanted to read it live because I was going to ask you, I had a picture of him and what have you.
John Lewis was like a couple of grades ahead of me in high school and he was one of the founders of SNCC, the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee.
That's what you told me a little bit over the phone with.
I talked with my history teacher a little bit about that.

and uh but john lewis was one of the founders of it um and after talking with king and john lewis you know they kind of formed a network among you know the youngsters and college students and that's john lewis and my hearing that speech you know
Right.
Had me on my way.
So did you start, did you do some stuff with SNCC, or did you?
Yeah, we went around to a lot of college chapters and helped organize SNCC's chapters.
We sat at some counters, lunch counters.
Oh, y'all did?
At the Woolworths, or just at the any?
Yeah, at the Woolworths.
You know, well, they would do a pick a target.
And then, because a lot of times the local people, so much pressure could be put on them.
Our side was, as they called us, troublemakers.
We would go in and test them.
There were no laws at the time, but to call attention to the problem.
The Civil Rights Bill wasn't passed until the mid-60s.
Johnson really got an accommodation bill, I think, prior to Johnson.
Civil rights legislation didn't come until Johnson, until Johnson did.
Well, did they have training sets?
Yeah, they trained you how to ball up and how to protect your vital parts.
They did that.
So then when y'all went around and helped the other chapters, y'all did that?
Told you how not to say things or do things that would inflame people, and they tested.
your ability to be peaceful.
To hold your tempers back?
Yeah.
They would berate you verbally and maybe assault you verbally.
If you could, just sit there calmly and quietly and let them.
The whole objective was not for you
react, but to show the world how these people really were and put them in a bad light.
And most of the time, you got obliged.
Right.
Well, when the TV, we talked about just about that time that, especially in Birmingham, when they started marching, that a lot of that started on TV, and that's when people became aware of that.
Aware of what was really going on, right.

so yeah you wanted to see that uh i remember that there was a public uh riding you know like the greyhound bus um of course the bus that i was on it didn't nothing but the buses john lewis and some of them were on that was the famous bus that was burned that was um he was on that bus when one of the free call them the freedom riders right
But there were, you know, numerous things that, you know, numerous marches that Tuskegee itself.
We went to Birmingham prior to the Great Birmingham March.
Great Birmingham Rides, really, I guess you would call it.
And we sat down a few places.
But they didn't get, you know, the notoriety that we were put in jail, surrounded by the Ku Klux Klan and all this kind of thing.
Did they have the, they didn't have, I just saw, I just, the one thing I remember from seeing that is like the fire hoses that they had out in, in that.
Yeah.
I wasn't in that, no.
They didn't have that when you were before that?
No, I demand they just burn you and beat you.
You know, they take cigarettes and you see nothing.
Gosh.
And they can assault you verbally, kick you, beat you, and the police will be standing right there.
And doing nothing, just standing there and looking?

Um, did you feel like it was about, when did you feel like the people really started getting frustrated, like, from this, I mean, I know probably there was frustration all along, but when people started turning more towards, um, like, black power instead of just this not peaceful non-violence, or did you?
I think basically, um, black power had its, uh, moments, but I don't think that black power ever really, uh,
caught on in the black community.
I know it was during this time that John Lewis and a lot of the original people in SNCC got out of it when Stokely Carmichael and Ralph Brown started doing this.
Because it was a policy that really would only lead to genocide, the types of things they were actively seeking.
You know, you didn't have the weaponry, you didn't have the numbers, you had nothing to wage any type of war of any time, of any length or duration, so there was a few left.
Which is what they wanted to do.
Yeah, yeah.

Ultimately, they hollered the black power, and black power of itself to the thinking people, you know, people who had, you know, started this thing a long time before they came along with an empty holler, that's all.
It meant nothing.
It had nothing.
It frightened people.
And Dr. King and the original SNCC people, they wanted not to frighten whites, but to elicit the supports of whites who were right.
And black power had the opposite effect of what the movement started out to be.
So there were those blacks, or like whites,
who think that violence and all of this can handle it.
But in the end, it would have proved, if it had been an all-out black-white struggle, it would have ended in chaos and you wouldn't have won.

So did you, like when you said John Lewis and all those started dropping out of SNCC, was that when they started, like a lot of the white little students from the north that were in there, when that's when they started ousting and that's when they, was that when they started leaving?
Yeah, that's when they started leaving it.
And I'll never forget, it started, the focus started going someplace else.
And I guess the most graphic thing, I can remember being in Mississippi, and we were talking, trying to get people to support galvanized and everything.
And there was this fringe of SNCC people who were honoring black power.
And there was a man, an old man, laying on that farm, black farmer, who got up and said
You can holler black power all you want.
And he wasn't dressed nice.
He had on all broken hands and two or three pair overalls.
But he reached inside those overalls, and he had a roll of like $100 bills.
And he said, this is power.
And this is where we need to go.
And he said, if you have money in America, you got power.
And I know for me, that was kind of a telling thing.
The laws were fine and everything like that, but money really was the equalizer.
So, so you never really moved in or became involved with that?
Well, not with the Black Power thing too much, no.
Um, mine was like in the early years, like, I only was only for a brief period, say like 59 through 61.
when I was involved after that time.
You know, I was sending money and what have you, but after getting kicked out of Tuskegee and coming to Texas and, you know, I... You came out, you didn't get your... No, I didn't graduate.
I was a radical at the time, and you have to understand the situation.
That Tuskegee Institute, unlike Texas A&M, even though they are both,
had the military tradition.
They both were fine agricultural and mechanical schools.
Both Tuskegee had, at the time I attended, one of the top 10 veterinary schools in the nation.
There was no integration.
The state of Alabama subsidized Tuskegee.
I'm saying this now.
I didn't know why at the time.
like I later found out.
I knew it was something.
I just thought they were on the tone at the time, the white president and dean and all those people.
But I found out why they did what they did.
The state supported Tuskegee's Veterinary Medicine School, the engineering school, and all of these things.
Because they didn't want anybody to go to the University of Alabama.
They didn't want blacks to go to the University of Alabama.
Auburn, see, Auburn is about 30 miles from Tuskegee, over 30 miles.
And they didn't, the legislators pressured these people and said, look, you know, you put out these radicals, you know, you're going to withdraw your funds.
And I just feel that that was one of the reasons why a lot of us
force to leave.
Even though, you know, I was an honor student.
Really?
And everything, but because I was a part of that radical element, you know, I had to go.
That threatened there.
Yeah.
I had to go.
So did, um, so when you came here, then, um, is that when you became active in the NAACP here?
I came to Waco.
Okay.
And I, uh, I was a black minister in my hometown who, uh, looked
who had gone to school with the president, then president, of Paul Quinn College.
And I haven't been in the South in a lot of those colleges.
A lot of them, the state school and things, that's in Walrus.
But he called them, and they accepted me, and transcript and everything.
I went to Tuskegee.
I mean, I finished with Paul Quinn College.
I didn't know anybody in Texas either.
I thought everybody in Texas was rich.
I owned the oil wells.
Really?
Did the what?
Owned the oil wells.
Oh, yeah.
You know, the only Texans I'd ever seen had the long boots and Continentals, Lincolns, Caddacks, big ass and horses and I just, I had this misconception of Texas.
Most people feel that people in the South were dumb and backwards and poor and all those kind of things.
But that's how I got to Texas.
And after graduating from Paul Quinn, then I came to Bryant High School for 12 years, 12 and a half years.
That's a lot.
I'm going to turn this over real quick.
